CollectionCitations.Title: Multi-Satellite Lambertian Equivalent Reflectivity (Local Satellite Time) 1 day L3 Global 5.0deg Lat Zones V1

EntryTitle: Multi-Satellite Lambertian Equivalent Reflectivity (Local Satellite Time) 1 day L3 Global 5.0deg Lat Zones V1 (MSLERLSTL3zm) at GES DISC

PublicationReferences.Author: Herman, J.R., G. Labow, N.C. Hsu, and D. Larko
PublicationReferences.Title: Changes in cloud and aerosol cover (1998 - 2006) from reflectivity time series using SeaWiFS, N7 - TOMS, EP - TOMS, SBUV - 2, and OMI radiance data

PublicationReferences.Author: Herman, J.R., M.T. DeLand, L. - K. Huang, et al.
PublicationReferences.Title: A net decrease in the Earth's cloud plus aerosol reflectivity during the past 33 yr (1979-2011) and increased solar heating at the surface

PublicationReferences.Author: Labow, G.J., J.R. Herman, L. - K. Huang, et al.
PublicationReferences.Title: Diurnal variation of 340 nm Lambertian Equivalent Reflectivity due to clouds and aerosol over land and oceans

Quality: These data were produced under the NASA MEaSUREs program with the goal being to apply a consistent instrument to instrument calibration so that the data could be used for long term trend analysis. The quality of the LER data varied depending on the instrument. In particular, the SBUV/2 data from NOAA 9, 11 and 14 are of somewhat lower quality due to various issues (Herman et al., 2012). The Nimbus7 TOMS, Earth Probe TOMS, Aura OMI and SeaStar SeaWiFS data are not a part of the common calibration. The Nimbus7 TOMS, Earth Probe TOMS, Aura OMI and SeaStar SeaWiFS data are not a part of the common calibration.

RelatedUrls.Description: Access the dataset landing page from the GES DISC website.
Access the data via the OPeNDAP protocol.
Access the data using the THREDDS Catalog.

Abstract:
The Multi-Satellite Lambertian Equivalent Reflectivity (Local Satellite Time) 1 day L3 Global 5.0deg Lat Zones data product (MSLERLSTL3zm) is derived from observations made by the Nimbus-7 SBUV, and NOAA 9, 11, 14, 16, 17, 18, 19 SBUV/2 instruments (340 nm), Nimbus-7 and Earth Probe TOMS (331 nm), OMI (340 nm) and SeaWiFS (412 nm) from 1978 to 2011. The Local Satellite Time (LST) data are uncorrected for the drift of the local equator crossing time of the spacecraft. The table below lists the date ranges for each instrument (note A = ascending node, D = descending node):

Instrument            Start Date    End Date
------------------    ----------    ----------
Nimbus-7 SBUV         1978-11-01    1990-06-21
NOAA-9 SBUV/2  (A)    1985-02-02    1991-09-03
NOAA-9 SBUV/2  (D)    1990-04-25    1997-05-31
NOAA-11 SBUV/2 (A)    1988-12-01    1995-03-31
NOAA-11 SBUV/2 (D)    1997-07-15    2001-03-26
NOAA-14 SBUV/2 (A)    1995-02-05    2002-09-11
NOAA-14 SBUV/2 (D)    2002-04-09    2006-09-28
NOAA-16 SBUV/2 (A)    2000-10-03    2009-09-15
NOAA-16 SBUV/2 (D)    2008-04-28    2012-12-31
NOAA-17 SBUV/2        2002-07-10    2012-12-31
NOAA-18 SBUV/2        2005-06-05    2012-12-12
Nimbus-7 TOMS         1978-11-01    1993-05-06
EarthProbe TOMS       1996-07-25    2004-06-21
Aura OMI              2005-01-01    2008-12-31
SeaStar SeaWiFS       1998-01-01    2008-12-30

The scene reflectivities of the Earth at blue and ultraviolet (UV) wavelengths (320 nm to 415 nm) are low over most surfaces (except ice and snow), and are almost independent of the seasonal changes in vegetation on land and in the oceans. This makes it ideal for examining changes in radiation reflected back to space from changes in cloud and aerosol amounts, especially as affected by the start of climate change.

The MSLERLSTL3zm data are archived in the HDF-EOS5 file format using the Zonal Average (ZA) model. The product consists of a single data file representing the entire data set containing the individual instrument data in separate time versus latitude arrays. Each data array contains attributes describing the variable, and the file contains metadata stored in the HDFEOS file attribute section
